Ecco a voi i 5 tipi di ciclisti da evitare assolutamente! 
Tagga il compagno di allenamento che appartiene ad una di queste categorie 👇

@bianchibicycles @dmtcycling @castellicycling @tissot_official @garminitaly @toyota_italia @kask_sport @koo_world @namedsport

node.text:
🏔🚵The mountains have always been the setting of the most memorable feats of the Giro. When the gradients go up, the metres feel like kilometres, and the seconds feel like minutes. The mountains are where the legends of cycling, from Bartali to Bernal, scored their greatest achievements.
Countless key moments have been played out on the mountains. Here are the best ones from the 2021 Giro d’Italia.
•
🏔🚵Le montagne, da sempre, sono il capitolo dove il Giro ha scritto le sue pagine più memorabili; quando la strada s'impenna i metri diventano chilometri e i secondi minuti. Sulle montagne sono nate le grandi imprese e i miti del ciclismo, da Bartali a Bernal.
Le montagne sono una raccolta di momenti decisivi. Qui abbiamo raccolto i migliori del Giro d'Italia 2021.

@italiait
#Giro

node.text:
❤️ A journey of 3,411 km, from Turin to Milan, from Filippo Ganna’s first Maglia Rosa, to Egan Bernal’s final one.
With astonishing feats in between: Sagan claiming the Maglia Ciclamino, Fortunato conquering the Zoncolan. 
The rain and the sun, the wind and the dust. The bravery of the breakaway riders, and Caruso’s surprising performance.
And again, colourful umbrellas floating in city streets, the glistening blue sea, the white roads of Tuscany, and the lush green forests of the Alps.
Relive all the best moments of the 2021 Giro d’Italia with us!
•
❤️ Un viaggio lungo 3411 km da Torino a Milano, dalla prima Maglia Rosa di Filippo Ganna all’ultima di Egan Bernal.
In mezzo scenari mozzafiato, la Maglia Ciclamino di Sagan e l’impresa di Fortunato sullo Zoncolan, pioggia, sole, vento e polvere, il coraggio dei fuggitivi e la favola di Caruso. 
E poi città dipinte da ombrelli colorati, il luccicare del mare azzurro, le strade bianche di Toscana e i boschi verdi delle Alpi.
Tutto il meglio del Giro d’Italia 2021, da rivedere assieme.

#Giro #GirodItalia

node.text:
🇨🇴🚴‍♂🏆
Let’s look back at Egan Bernal’s journey through the Giro, from his attack on the off-road summit finish of Campo Felice to the gravel roads of Montalcino, from his splendid solo victory in Cortina, through his meltdown in Sega di Ala, to his final accomplishment in Milan.
A journey that started in Zipaquirá 24 years ago, and which ultimately led him to Piazza Duomo in May this year, where he sealed his first Giro d’Italia title, lifting the Trofeo Senza Fine, clad in the leader’s jersey.
•
🇨🇴🚴‍♂🏆
Tutto il viaggio di Egan Bernal a questo Giro: dall’attacco sullo sterrato di Campo Felice alla polvere di Montalcino, dalla cavalcata solitaria di Cortina alla crisi di Sega di Ala, fino ad arrivare al trionfo finale di Milano. 
Un viaggio iniziato a Zipaquirá 24 anni fa e che l’ha portato questo maggio in Piazza Duomo - dove ha sollevato il Trofeo Senza Fine indossando la Maglia Rosa, dove ha conquistato il suo primo Giro d’Italia. 
@eganbernal

#Giro #GirodItalia #MagliaRosa #EganBernal

node.text:
🔙 Fernando Gaviria was born on August 19, 1994 in La Ceja, a town in the Department of Antioquia, 45 kilometres away from the capital, Medellin.He is the son of former cyclist José Hernando, and the brother of track cyclist – sprint and Keirin specialist – Juliana Gaviria.

Having grown up in a family like this, it was no surprise that he ended up riding a bicycle from an early age. Fernando came to prominence at the Tour de San Luis, where he beat a certain Mark Cavendish twice. “The first time I beat Mark, I couldn’t sleep at night. I was too excited. I could not believe I had defeated the best sprinter in the world, the one I would cheer on when I was a child, on the couch at home...”

🟣 The 2017 Giro d’Italia marked the eventual consecration for the Colombian sprinter. Nailing four stage victories and taking the points jersey, Fernando proved he was no less than unstoppable.

🎂 Happy birthday, Fernando! Leave your birthday wishes for the winner of the 2017 Maglia Ciclamino! 👇

.

🔙 Fernando Gaviria è nato il 19 agosto 1994, viene da La Ceja, pueblo del Dipartimento di Antioquia, a 45 km dal capoluogo Medellin. Suo padre, José Hernando, era un ciclista. Sua sorella, Juliana, è una pistard, specialista di velocità e keirin.

In una famiglia così non è certo una sorpresa ritrovarsi in giovane età su una bicicletta. 
La stella di Fernando è nata al Tour de San Luis quando per ben due volte si è imposto su un certo Mark Cavendish. “Le vittorie su Mark? Dopo la prima non ho dormito la notte per l'emozione, non mi sembrava vero. Battere il miglior velocista del pianeta, quello per il quale tifavo da bambino sul divano di casa...".

🟣 Al Giro d’Italia del 2017 arriva la consacrazione per il velocista Colombiano: 4 vittorie di tappa e la conquista della Maglia Ciclamino. Semplicemente inarrestabile. 

🎂 Buon compleanno Fernando! Lascia i tuoi auguri di compleanno al vincitore della Maglia Ciclamino del 2017! 👇

[📸 @bettiniphoto ]

#giro #fernandogaviria

node.text:
Looking at Gino Bartali’s record of achievements, there is no doubt that he was one of the most important riders in the history of world cycling. He won anything he could, and hadn’t it been for the war, he would have achieved even more. Still, if we look at Gino Bartali, we cannot separate the athlete from the man. His human side is what has earned ‘Ginettaccio’ the love of all the Italians.He was a passionate man, both in the saddle and in everyday life. 

He was rude, resolved and overconfident but big-hearted. During those terrible years for Italy, he was a symbol of rebirth for everybody. Cranky and coarse, he was nicknamed ‘the iron man’ or ‘Ginettaccio’. We only found after his death all the good things he did, and not just for Italy. In May 2005, the Italian President Ciampi posthumously awarded him the gold medal for civil merit, and on September 23, 2013, he was recognized as Righteous Among the Nations – a title that is awarded by Israel to non-Jewish individuals who took great risks to save at least one Jew during World War II.

“Good is something you do, not something you talk about. Some medals are pinned to your soul, not to your jacket”.

Gino Bartali [18 July 1914 – 5 May 2000]

#Giro #ginobartali

node.text:
💪 He would never lose his temper. He would never stand on the pedals.
If we had to define Miguel Indurain using just one word or two, ‘rock-hard’ would suit him the most.

⏱️ The Spanish ace was one of the best time trialists. He would ride as if he were one with his bike, biting the tarmac and gaining a significant lead one pedal stroke at a time. Along the climbs, a harsh terrain for a bulky rider like he was, he would never strike back. Rather, he would limit the losses by managing the lead he had gained in time trials.

“I inherited that calm from my father, who was a farmer. You sow, you wait for good or bad weather, you harvest, but working is something you always need to do”.

Calm, dedication and hard work were the foundation of his success at the Giro d’Italia. He was the first rider to conquer two consecutive editions of the Corsa Rosa since Eddy Merckx, and after him, no other rider succeeded in doing so.

🎂 Happy birthday, Miguel! Do you know how the Spanish ace was called? Write his nickname in the comments! 👇

-

💪 Senza mai alzarsi sui pedali, senza mai perdere la calma. 
Se c’è una parola con cui forse possiamo definire Miguel Indurain è “granitico”.

⏱️ Il campione spagnolo è stato uno dei migliori interpreti delle prove contro il tempo. Era capace di diventare un tutt’uno con la bici, divorare l’asfalto e imporre distacchi incredibili ai suoi avversari. In salita, un terreno difficile per un corridore della sua stazza, non rispondeva mai agli attacchi dei suoi rivali e riusciva a limitare i danni grazie ai vantaggi accumulati nelle cronometro. 

"Ho ereditato questa calma da mio padre, che era un contadino. Si semina, si aspetta il tempo buono o cattivo, si raccoglie, ma lavorare è qualcosa che bisogna sempre fare”.

I successi del campione spagnolo al Giro d’Italia sono stati tutti costruiti con la calma e il duro lavoro. Dopo di lui, nessuno è riuscito a vincere due Giri d’Italia consecutivi e fu il primo a vincere due edizioni consecutive dai tempi di Eddy Merckx.

🎂 Buon compleanno Miguel! Sapete qual era il soprannome del campione spagnolo? Scrivilo nei commenti! 👇

[ 📸 @bettiniphoto ] #giro #miguelindurain

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Giro d'Italia on July 16, 2021 tagging @stefanogarzelli. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
🔙 Who knows what Marco Pantani and Stefano Garzelli said to each other the night before stage 19 of the 2000 Giro d’Italia. Stefano had entered the Giro as an aid to his teammate, Marco Pantani. As Marco was not in his best shape, however, the team manager at Mercatone realised that a change in strategy was required to stand any chance of winning. After Stefano Garzelli finished in second on the Abetone, it became clear that he was the one to rely on, so he was appointed as new captain. This was a chance of a lifetime for him, an opportunity that only comes up rarely in a rider’s career. Stefano seized the moment and made the most of it. He raced cleverly and consistently, prepared to strike a decisive blow in time trials.

The key moment arrived on stage 19, on the Izoard. All the strongest climbers – Casagrande, Frigo, Simoni and Gotti – had joined forces against Stefano, as it often happens in cycling when the bunch needs to get rid of a rival with strong time-trial skills. Their goal was to close off Garzelli, and cast him adrift on the punishing final climb.

That day, however, Garzelli had an extraordinary domestique: Marco Pantani. The ‘Pirate’ moved forward at the foot of the Izoard and drilled it for his captain, setting a break-neck pace that prevented everybody from gaining more than one metre. Stefano bit the bullet and sat firmly on his wheel, without giving up. When he reached the summit among the best-placed finishers, the Maglia Rosa was a mere 25 seconds away.

The following day, Stefano Garzelli took the overall lead in the ITT, and on 4 June 2000 he rolled down the streets of Milan wearing the Maglia Rosa, eventually winning the Giro d’Italia.

🎂 Happy birthday, Stefano! Drop your birthday wishes for the winner of the 2000 Giro d’Italia below! 👇

#giroditalia #stefanogarzelli 
[ 📸 PIC. @bettiniphoto ]

Con il progetto 🌲 @regalaunalbero 🌲 di Ride Green Banca Mediolanum è stato regalato un albero per ogni corridore partecipante alla Corsa, per un totale di 184 alberi, oltre a 21 alberi ad ogni Maglia Azzurra di giornata. mille alberi per il Vincitore del Giro d’Italia e 6 sono stati piantati per le città più virtuose del progetto #RideGreen.

With 🌲 “@regalaunalbero”🌲 Ride Green Banca Mediolanum project was able to donate a tree for each rider taking part in the race, for a total of 184 trees, as well as 21 trees, one for each Maglia Azzurra, thousand trees for the winner of the Giro d'Italia and 6 trees for the most virtuous stage cities on Ride Green project.
#giro #giroditalia

node.text:
In 2021, Ride Green @bancamediolanum truly demonstrated the results of this winning formula, with an extraordinary result: over 46,000 kg of waste was collected during the Corsa Rosa, of which 85% was separated and sent for recycling.
Here the most virtuous stage cities:
Stage Start 🚩
🥇 Siena (91,07% RD)
🥈 Modena (90,98% RD)
🥉 Nichelino in provincia di Torino (90,60% RD) 
Stage Finish 🏁
🥇 Sestola in provincia di Modena (92,05% RD)
🥈 Montalcino in provincia di Siena (91,57% RD) 
🥉 Novara (90,60% RD)

Anche nel 2021 Ride Green @bancamediolanum si conferma vincente, con un risultato straordinario: con oltre 46.000 chilogrammi di rifiuti raccolti durante la Corsa Rosa di cui l’85% differenziati e avviati al riciclo. 
Ecco i comuni premiati:
Partenza 🚩
🥇 Siena (91,07% RD)
🥈 Modena (90,98% RD)
🥉 Nichelino in provincia di Torino (90,60% RD) 
Arrivo 🏁
🥇 Sestola in provincia di Modena (92,05% RD)
🥈 Montalcino in provincia di Siena (91,57% RD) 
🥉 Novara (90,60% RD)
